comment: Thanks for the videos professor
Thanks 🤍❤️

Just wondering why he chose x=a*sin(t), y=b*cos(t) (my generisation) instead of the more common x=a*cos(t), y=b*sin(t) as parametric equation of ellipse? The x=...sin... form is then analogous to the circle form and makes life easier for the students; and the 'direction' is the same.
Most glaring thing about raising trigfunctions in powers is that the reciprocal (-1) is used as showing arcus-functions eg. inverse trigs, not reciprocal.

Props to Saurav Bastola, https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC7hkeE-LRyzietNCecWnHLg for the listed topics. Why can't dx/dy be squared to become dx^2/dy^2 ? After all, dx/dy can be treated as two separate number when solving a separable differential equation. Aren't dx and dy just two very small number that shrink to as low as you want, so that they present no significant value - have so many zero's in them after the decimal point-  that each of them is near enough to zero to ignore, but their ratio remains the same so that the slope can be found.

lol never seen some1 put a period at the end of their equation (around 7:10)
James Arnes That notation will look too similar to the 2nd derivative.

Suppose y=f(x) which is a function of single variable x, then y=f'(x)=dy/dx, so y=f''(x) can be notated as (d/dx)*(dy/dx) = d^2y/dx^2. In this case y is a function and x is a variable and 'd' is used to notate differentiation, but in case of (dy/dx) which prof. mentioned 'dy' and 'dx' itself denotates the infinitesimal value just as in linear approximation.
So not only to discern the denotation of 'dx' and 'd', but also avoid the confusion in terms of marking
nevermind, the '2' in '2sin(t)' is the "missing constant" I was looking for.

it is assume
you can interpret  ds/dt as change in the way you walk on circle's circumference with respect to t =time which is speed in physics

Because we cover the circumference after 2pi units of time (if that's how you want to think of t). And 2pi*a is the circumference, so we had to have covered it at speed a. If the origin wasn't at the center, then x or y would be shifted, but that wouldn't affect the speed which would still be a, since the hanging constants don't affect our differentiation (or, we still cover the period of the sine and cosine functions after 2pi units of t).
